author: Tim Wallace
title: Clydesdale Bank pitches to investors ahead of flotation
text: The Clydesdale bank sets out its stall to its investors today, explaining just what shareholders will be buying into if they invest in the lenders’ shares when they go public this year . National Australia Bank owns the Clydesdale and Yorkshire Bank brands, but has struggled to make a sustainable return on the UK operations. It wants to float the pair off under the Clydesdale name, with NAB’s shareholders keeping 70pc to 80pc of the lender and new investors coming in to buy the remaining 20pc to 30pc. Payment protection insurance mis-selling has been a key problem for the bank, with redress costs coming in at £670m from 2012 to 2014, and the bank was fined £21m this year for poor PPI complaints handling. But the Clydesdale is basing its pitch to investors on a picture where these problems are on the decline, while the bank is well placed to take advantage of regional economic growth in the UK. Since 2012, it has re-shaped its loan book to strip out commercial real estate completely, and increased the secured retail – largely mortgages – component of its loans from 46pc of its book to 69pc. The presentation to investors is also a chance to introduce its new chief executive David Duffy to shareholders. Mr Duffy took over in June, after leaving his job at the top of Allied Irish Bank – another major challenge, as the bank had been bailed out in the financial crisis. Clydesdale says its Yorkshire and Scottish heartlands mean it is well-placed to capitalise on the Uk's economic growth The Clydesdale’s presentation notes that it is the biggest of the UK’s mid-sized banks, with £28bn of loans, just above Virgin Money’s £23bn and TSB’s £22bn. The Clydesdale calls itself “the only UK mid-market bank which has material scale, full service capabilities and substantially standalone IT platform,” drawing a contrast with the others in the same size bracket, which also includes the Co-operative Bank and will include RBS’ spin-off Williams and Glyn . Although it only has 3.1pc of the UK’s personal current account market, the bank has 9.3pc in its core markets in Scotland and northern England. And the Clydesdale highlights the increasingly competitive market, with the seven day current account switching scheme and the emergence of several high-profile entrants to the market encouraging customers to shop around. The Clydesdale has a 1.6pc share of the UK mortgage market, and a 3.9pc share in its core markets. Mortgage lending volumes have risen buy 15pc over the past three years, to 1.2m transactions in 2014. The bank predicts sustained house price growth, and tells investors that the growth should be particularly strong outside London and the South East, and so relatively stronger in its core markets. Its IPO will follow those of TSB last summer , Virgin Money in November 2014, Aldermore in March 2015 and Shawbrook Bank in April . Follow the Telegraph on LinkedIn.
